Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Transient Jets and Re-Ignition for Energy Efficiency Gains from Confined Combustion

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: Combustible fuel-air mixtures can be ignited, intentionally or not, by a transient jet, a puff, of hot reactive gas from an adjacent combustion event. This re-ignition phenomenon differs greatly from common electric spark or compression ignition events. Whether or not, and how quickly, re-ignition occurs depends on a complex interaction of physical and chemical processes occurring at different rates: puff vortex spinning, mixing and fuel molecule oxidation. Preliminary experiments show good agreement with gas motion predictions, but also indicate that re-ignition delay time depends on the fuel-air ratio in a way that is as yet unexplained. This project will use computational, experimental, and analytical approaches to investigate re-ignition by transient jets that mix residual or re-injected combustion gases and fresh mixtures, establish the re-ignition delay time for common gaseous fuels, and determine their sensitivities to key parameters. Computational models will be used to predict puff vortex dynamics and reacting mixture temperature in stationary and traversing jets. Experiments will verify vortex dynamics and measure re-ignition delay times for traversing and stationary jets through the use of pressure sensors, visualization, and optical diagnostics. A simplified mathematical model will then be developed to carefully disentangle the gas mixing and chemical processes, and more accurately predict re-ignition. Fuel oxidation theory validated in other types of combustion will be tested for applicability to jet re-ignition. Scientists at a company partnering in this project will not only guide the project itself, but also mentor a doctoral candidate in applying the research findings at the company.

Broad Impacts: This project will enable jet-ignited combustion approaches aimed at dramatic reductions in fuel consumption and greenhouse gas emissions in a wide range of power plants. The success of this project has the potential to transform many of the ways in which fuel has been consumed since the Industrial Revolution. It leads directly to novel combustion methods that create a pressure boost in aircraft and electric power generation engines. By retrofitting or redesigning power generation gas turbines and aircraft jet engines with pressure-boost combustors, the United States can save an estimated $10 billion dollars in fuel and 100 megatons of CO2 emissions each year. The project will help develop pressure-boost combustion technology using a device called a wave rotor combustor. This disruptive technology can also enable innovative medium- and small-scale power generators as well as more efficient hybrid vehicles and portable power units. Additionally, the project enables more reliable ignition in trucks and locomotives using internal combustion engines, allowing the substitution of less expensive, domestic gas fuels for diesel refined from imported petroleum. Transient jets from small pre-chambers can accomplish consistent ignition of natural gas while reducing nitrogen oxide emissions and avoiding diesel smoke. The results of this research will be immediately utilized in concurrent but separate wave rotor combustor experiments, with simplified models being incorporated into design codes usable by industry. The doctoral candidate will assist the industry partner in the development of a wave rotor combustor prototype, the initial goal of which is reducing fuel consumption, carbon emissions, and the weight of gas turbines by about 20% each.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Re-ignition by a transient jet, a puff, of hot reactive gas is key to the development of novel pressure-gain combustion systems, such as a wave rotor combustor to greatly improve gas turbine engine efficiency and reduce carbon emissions. This project used computational, experimental, and analytical approaches to investigate re-ignition by a transient jet that mixes re-injected combustion gases and fresh mixtures in a confined-volume chamber similar to a wave rotor channel. The jet source nozzle is either stationary or traversing across one end of the chamber as occurs in a wave rotor. Transient jets from small pre-chambers can also accomplish consistent ignition of lean mixtures in internal-combustion engines. This enables reduction of NOx emissions, and promotes adoption of natural gas as an alternate fuel for trucks and cars, thus reducing air pollution and imported petroleum use.

Reynolds-averaged (RANS) models were used to predict puff vortex dynamics and reacting mixture conditions in stationary and traversing jets. Ignition delay is defined to include both physical jet mixing and chemical kinetic processes, and may also be influenced by shock-flame interactions for less reactive mixtures in the confined volume. Affordable two-dimensional RANS simulations with reduced mechanisms showed that physical effects were usually more important than chemical factors. Initial temperature of the mixture in the range 300-500 K had no significant effect on the ignition delay. Pre-ignition gas properties were examined to develop and verify a criterion to predict ignition delay time using lower-cost non-reacting flow simulation. The jet evolution, vortex structure and mixing behavior are significantly different for traversing jets, stationary centered jets, and near-wall jets. Shock-wave traverse of the reaction zone significantly increased the overall reaction rate, due to baroclinic vorticity generation that stirs reactants and increases flame area. Preliminary large-eddy simulation with hybrid turbulent-kinetic schemes using skeletal reaction mechanisms revealed that ignition may occur rapidly in the jet shear layer for highly reactive fuels, or in the head vortex for less reactive fuels.

The ignition delay time was measured for various blends of hydrogen and methane, including sensitivities to jet momentum, mixture equivalence ratio, fuel reactivity, and, to a limited extent, the traverse speed of the jet. The experimental apparatus consists of two combustion chambers: a pre chamber that generates the transient hot jet of gas from fuel-rich combustion, and a main chamber which contains the main fuel-air blend under study, preheated by an attached air heater. The reactivity and energy density of the mixture was varied using different fuel blends, equivalence ratios, and initial temperature. The jet momentum was varied using different initial pressures in the pre-chamber. Dynamic pressure sensors recorded at up to 300 kHz while the vortex, shock, and flame dynamics were visualized using high-speed Schlieren videography at about 20,000 frames per second. Ignition delay was generally shortest with a slightly rich pre-chamber mixture, and consistently lengthened with higher main-chamber equivalence ratio in the range of 0.4 to 1.5 for all cases, and with increase in methane fraction of the blend. Consistent with predictions but still surprising, temperature of the main chamber mixture in the range 300-500 K was found not to affect hot jet ignition delay significantly. Physical effects, such as shear layer diffusion, vortex mixing, and shock-flame interactions appeared to have a greater effect on hot jet ignition delay than chemical kinetics, even with pure methane fuel with its relatively slow kinetics. There appears to be an optimal traversing rate for shortest ignition delay, but traversing case data was limited by mechanical limits and data acquisition challenges that are being addressed.

Two types of simplified mathematical models are being developed to predict re-ignition, one for high Damkohler number when ignition is more likely to occur in the shear layer, and one for low Damkohler when ignition is more likely to occur in the head vortex of the transient jet. Through an exact solution of momentum equation for a starting round jet, the rate of mass entrainment in the near field was estimated.

The results of this research were immediately utilized in concurrent but separate wave rotor combustor development and commercialization. The PI took a sabbatical leave from teaching and administration during this project and formed a startup company, which was awarded and completed an NSF small business technology transfer (STTR) Phase I project to develop a wave rotor combustor prototype in collaboration with a major aircraft engine company.

The project trained two post doctoral researchers and seven graduate students in combustion and ignition processes. Six students completed MS thesis, and one PhD student made substantial progress toward dissertation. The project also provided about 45 undergraduate students to perform non-curricular research or capstone design projects with the group’s guidance. Over 50 middle-school and high-school students from underrepresented minority backgrounds attended presentations in the PI’s laboratory during four summers, learning about aircraft propulsion, combustion, and optical phenomena.
